sentence.text: ï»¿Patient 2 (V-3) is a relative of Patient 1 (Fig. 1A) and is the second child of healthy consanguineous parents from Mayotte Island.
The birth parameters of Patient 2 were unknown.
At 8 months of age, his weight was 7.3 kg (25th centile), his height was 68 cm (10th centile), and head circumference was 43 cm (25th centile).
He presented turricephaly with craniosynostosis of all sutures.

Dysmorphic features included a prominent metopic ridge, a flat nasal bridge, epicanthic folds, hypertelorism, ocular proptosis, low set ears, mandibular hypoplasia, high palate, polysyndactyly of hands and feet (Fig. 2A), and genu valgum.
Bilateral microcornea and corneal opacities were noted.
Radiographs of the hands showed brachydactyly with hypoplasia of the middle phalanges of the fingers (Fig. 2B).
Radiographs of the feet showed broad phalanges of both halluces with bifid distal phalanges, and hypoplasia of the middle phalanges of the second to the fifth toes.
Abdominal ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) were normal.
Cytogenetic study of peripheral lymphocytes was normal.
He had a patent ductus arteriosus which was closed percutaneously at 11 months of age and at 1 year of age, cranioplasty was performed.
At 13 months of age, surgery was performed on each hand to remove the extra postaxial digits and to correct the syndactyly.
At 4 years of age, weight and height were in the normal range and his head circumference was 47 cm (10th centile).
